University of Auckland

An activity can be defined as a task or set of tasks a learner must complete. Provide a clear statement of the task and consider any conditions that may help or hinder the learner in the performance of the task.
Describe the tasks the learners should complete.

Movies have become very popular in the last century. It is the favorite pastime of many people across the world. The best thing about movies is that there are different genres. This means that everyone can find something interesting. Even though many movies are produced every year, there are some that are more popular than others. Movies have a part in influencing the masses and so are a great way of spreading information about things that affect the world.

  • Answer these questions in your notebook.

1. What type of movies do you like to watch?

2. Do you prefer watching films at the cinema or at home?

3. Do you have a favorite movie? If that is the case, which one is it and why? 

4. Who do you think plays the best role in a film making, the actors, the directors, the producers, or the screeenwriter? Why? 

Before you continue...                                                                           

This activity is destined for English IV, if you have a lower level it might be difficult for you to comprehend and answer some activities. 

In order to answer this activity, you need to have knowledge about the grammatical tenses (past, present and future) and their rules; also you need to know the difference between active and passive voice.. 

Survey
What will you learn?
Enter a question for learners to reflect upon.
Describe how learners will assess how they have done in the exercise (rubrics are useful devices for providing reflective feedback).
University of Auckland

Reflection is a teaching method often used to connect theory to practice. Reflection tasks often provide learners with an opportunity to observe and reflect on their observations before presenting these as a piece of academic work. Journals, diaries, profiles and portfolios are useful tools for collecting observation data. Rubrics and guides can be effective feedback tools.
Enter a question for learners to reflect upon.
Reflective question:

In this learning object you will learn vocabulary about the different types of movies and about the different people that make it possible to film a movie.

You will be taught about the causative verbs and their functions. You will differenciate the meaning and the use of the causative verbs.

You will solve several exercises to demostrate the knowledge acquired about these verbs.
Describe how learners will assess how they have done in the exercise (rubrics are useful devices for providing reflective feedback).
How much do you know about movies? Let's find out...
University of Auckland

An activity can be defined as a task or set of tasks a learner must complete. Provide a clear statement of the task and consider any conditions that may help or hinder the learner in the performance of the task.
Describe the tasks the learners should complete.

Read the information about movies. If you come across a word that you are not familiar with, continue reading and try to understand the context of the paragraph . Try reading the lines above , then below , repeat this until you understand the context and then confer the meaning of the word on your own with the help of context. In case you are still having problems to comprehend the word, look it up in the dictionary and write it down in your notebook to extend your vocabulary.

After reading the text, complete the activities with the information you just read.

Movie fans come in all different types as so the movies that they enjoy.  Films have covered every aspects of the human experience from showing serious struggles to reflecting history and also just making us laugh or even scream.  Like with all art forms, movies mirror human life and also influence it in many ways. Movies can be divided into several different genres. 

Action movies are usually about a conflict between a hero or a group of heroes and one or more villains. Movies like these almost always reach a climax near the end in which the hero and the villain meet for a final battle. This climax usually includes some of the movie's most spectacular scenes and special effects. Not all action movies feature heroes and villains. Some feature anti-heroes who face terrible dangers and will do whatever they have to do to survive. However, not all these films are ralated to super-heroes, there are others about high-speed car chases, martial arts, gun battles and big explosions.

Not everyone loves action movies, some people prefer to go to the cinema to watch serial killers, ghosts and monsters. Many early horror movies were based on old stories about scary creatures like vampires who terrify their victims by biting their necks and drinking their blood. Films about supernatural beings like ghosts and spirits, and movies about spooky places like haunted houses can be very scary as well. These movies use creepy sound effects and music that frighten even brave people. 

Since the early days of cinema, comedy has been one of its most popular and successful genres. A good comedy has lots of scenes with funny characters or funny situations that make us laugh.Characters can be funny if they're clever and say or do witty  things, or if they're socially inept and say or do embarrassing things, or if they're not very clever and they say and do stupid things. Scenes can be funny if something unexpected or shocking happens or if something embarrassing or ridiculous happens. Films that find humour in these and other serious topics like war, illness and death are often called black comedies. Movies that feature very strange or very crazy humour are often called absurd comedies. Another popular kind of comedy is the road movie in which characters have a series of funny adventures while travelling together. 

Comedy and drama were the earliest genres of cinema, and they're still the most popular genres today. Dramas entertain us by telling interesting stories. A good drama does more than just tell a good story, however. It makes us care about the characters and feel many emotions. If something good happens we feel like smiling, if something sad happens we feel like crying, and if something bad is done to a character we like we might even feel angry. If we feel emotions like these we'll get involved in the story and find it more entertaining. But dramas can do even more than this. They can also make us think about important issues and teach us important lessons about life and how to live. There are many different genres of drama and some of the most popular are the mystery, police drama, political drama, biopics that are about real people and docudramas about real events are also very popular. The variety is extense. 

There are other types of movies that are popular. If you love watching movies about the future or movies set in outer space, you're a fan of science fiction or "sci-fi". We might see what living in a high-tech future world could be like. We might see people travelling in time, or androids that look like human beings, or huge starships that travel to distant galaxies. But not just that, there are also movies that recall or are based on historical events in the past; or for those who are learning about the real world and real people probably like watching documentaries. 

After watching a movie, you might want to ask questions like:

  • "Which character did you like the best?"
  • "What did you think of the plot?"
  • "Did you like the cast?"
  • "What was your favourite scene?

It does not matter your personality or the things you are into, there is always going to be a film that will captivate you. If you have not find a favorite genre yet, keep watching movies!

Movies have become in one of the most important tools of communication and entertainment, and mass media in the 21h century. Just as there are different type of people with different personalities, there are different genres . There are comedies that make people laugh. Black comedies are those films that look at the funny side of things that we usually consider to be very serious , like death and illness. Along with comedy, drama movies were the first ones to appear on the big screen. This genre depends mostly on in-depth character development, interaction, and highly emotional themes. These movies make us smile or cry. Also there are other films that frighten us. Horror movies are about supernatural beings like ghosts and spirits. And for people who are not interented in any pf the previous genres, there are also sci-fi movies and documentaries.

Cloze exercises are texts or sentences where students must fill in missing words. They are often used for the following purposes:

  1. To check knowledge of core course concepts (this could be a pre-check, formative exercise, or summative check).
  2. To check reading comprehension.
  3. To check vocabulary knowledge.
  4. To check word formation and/or grammatical competence.

If your goal is to test understanding of core concepts or reading comprehension

Write a summary of the concept or reading long enough to adequately test the target's knowledge, but short enough not to induce fatigue. Less than one typed page is probably adequate, but probably considerably less for young students or beginners.

Select words in the text thatare key to understanding the concepts. Thesewill probably be verbs, nouns, and key adverbs.Choose alternatives with one clear answer.

If your goal is to test vocabulary knowledge

Write a text using the target vocabulary. This text should be coherent and cohesive, and be of an appropriate length. Highlight the target words in the text. Choose alternatives with one clear answer.

If your goal is to test word formation/grammar:

Write a text using the target forms. This text should be coherent and cohesive, and be of an appropriate length. Remember that the goal is not vocabulary knowledge, so the core meanings of the stem words should be well known to the students.

Highlight the target words in the text. Provide alternatives with the same word stem, but different affixes. It is a good idea to get a colleague to test the test/exercise to make sure there are no surprises!
Enter any feedback you wish to provide the learner with-in the feedback field. This field can be left blank.
How Many People Does It Take To Make a Movie?
University of Auckland

An activity can be defined as a task or set of tasks a learner must complete. Provide a clear statement of the task and consider any conditions that may help or hinder the learner in the performance of the task.
Describe the tasks the learners should complete.

Have you ever stopped to think about how many people it takes to make a movie? The exact number of people needed to make a movie depends upon the type of movie you're making. A short film that only shows one actor speaking directly to the camera would require only a few people at the most. On the other hand, a three-hour action movie with tons of special effects shot on location around the world could require thousands of people!

Let's take a closer look at some of the things you need to make a movie. To start with, you need a story. This usually takes the form of a written script, which is like a story with dialog and additional direction as to what action should take place during each scene. A script requires a screenwriter or sometimes even an entire team of writers.

A producer will come across an idea and start putting together all the elements to get a movie made. This can include security financing, as well as choosing the cast. 

One of the most important roles in filmmaking is the director. The director is the person mainly responsible for turning the story into a film, including making many of the creative decisions and directing the cast through the step-by-step filming of the scenes.

Most movies you have seen have many other people involved beyond just the producers, writers and director. Movies require actors, film crews, lighting and sound experts, make-up and costume professionals, stuntmen, extras, editors, technology experts, and a wide variety of other people to do everything from setting up and taking down sets to assisting all of the other people in countless different ways.

University of Auckland

An activity can be defined as a task or set of tasks a learner must complete. Provide a clear statement of the task and consider any conditions that may help or hinder the learner in the performance of the task.
Describe the tasks the learners should complete.

It really is very impressive to see all the people who are needed to make a film and how each one performs a very important role in order to produce a successful movie. Everyone needs the support of another person to be able to do his or her own part. The director needs the help of competent and committed actors to film each scene. Actors require make-up artists who design and apply the makeup for each actor/actress.  Make-up professionals use make-up to do their job, and someone else has to create the products. But not just that, stuntmen risk their lives doing the dangerous scenes so that the actors do not get hurt.  Every role is fundamental,it works like a puzzle, if a piece is missing it will not be complete.

Just as the actors need the help of someone else to do something for them, you need the help of others as well! Have you ever stopped to think about the services you obtain from others? Could you repair your own car? Could you fix your washing machine? If you couldn't or if you don't want to do these things yourself, you need to get someone to do them for you. 

When you want to express that someone else does something for you, the causative verbs are used. The English verbs let, make, have, and get are called causative verbs because they cause something else to happen. This form can be used in the different verb tenses and obviously the rules for each tense must be respected. 

How To Use Causative Verbs In English?

LET = permit something to happen.

Grammatical structure:

  • LET + PERSON/THING + VERB (base form)

Example:

  • I don’t let my kids watch violent movies.  (Present simple)
  • The director let the actors take a rest after every scene. (Present simple)
  • Oops! I wasn’t paying attention while cooking because I was watching my favorite movie at the same time, and I let the food burn.   (Past simple)

MAKE = force or require someone to take an action.

Grammatical structure:

  • MAKE + PERSON + VERB (base form)

Examples:

  • Angelina Jolie makes her children behave properly.   (Present simple)
  • The director of the film will not make the film crew wear uniforms.  (Future simple)
  • After Billy broke my TV, his parents made him pay for it. (Past simple)

HAVE = give someone else the responsibility to do something.

Grammatical structure:

  • HAVE + PERSON + VERB (base form)

Examples of grammatical structure:

  • I’ll have my best friend buy the tickets for the movie. (Future simple)
  • The make-up artist had the actress choose the color of the shadow for her eyes. (Past simple)
  • The actors have the stuntmen perform the dangerous scenes.  (Present simple)

GET = convince/encourage someone to do something.

Grammatical structure:

  • GET + PERSON + TO + VERB (infinitive form)

Examples:

  • How can we get the actors to arrive on time? (Present simple)
  • Jennifer Aniston hates housework; her family can never get her to wash the dishes.  (Present simple)

If you pay close attention to the previous examples, you can notice that all of them are in active voice, active voice is used when the subject is the doer of the action. However, causative verbs can also be used in passive voice. Passive voice is used when the subject is the receiver of the action. The passive is used in these cases because we don’t always know who the doer of the action is. Only the verbs have and get are used in passive voice (Get is less formal). 

  • The teacher had the students do the assignment. (Active Form)
    (The teacher caused the students to do the assignment).
  • The teacher had the assignment done. (Passive Form)
    (We don’t know exactly who did the assignment, so this is like a passive)

Grammatical structure

  • HAVE/GET + THING + PAST PARTICIPLE OF VERB

Examples:

  • Jonny Deep had/got his teeth whitened; his smile looks great!  (Past simple) 
  • My cam recorder is broken; I need to have/get it repaired.  (Present simple)

True/false questions present a statement where the learner must decide if the statement is true. This type of question works well for factual information and information that lends itself to either/or responses.

If this option is checked, submitted answers with different capitalization will be marked as incorrect.

Example: I fixed the computer (active voice).  ⇒   I had the computer fixed.  (passive voice)   

1. I translated the documents. (have)  ⇒  I had the documents translated

2. I mowed the lawn. (have)  ⇒    I had the lawn mowed

3. I painted my bedroom. (get)  ⇒   I got my bedroom painted.

4. I repaired my fridge. (have)  ⇒   I had my fridge repaired.

5. I tidied my garden. (get)  ⇒   I got my garden tidied.

6. I edited the article. (have)  ⇒   I had the article edited.

8. I cleaned the carpets. (get)  ⇒   I got the carpets cleaned .

For example: If the correct answer is Elephant then both elephant and Eliphant will be judged "close enough" by the algorithm as it only has one letter wrong, even if "Check Capitalization" is on.

If capitalization checking is off in the above example, the lowercase e will not be considered a mistake and eliphant will also be accepted.

If both "Strict Marking" and "Check Capitalization" are set, the only correct answer is "Elephant". If only "Strict Marking" is checked and "Check Capitalization" is not, "elephant" will also be accepted.

Example: I fixed the computer (active voice).  ⇒   I had the computer fixed.  (passive voice)

Cloze exercises are texts or sentences where students must fill in missing words. They are often used for the following purposes:

  1. To check knowledge of core course concepts (this could be a pre-check, formative exercise, or summative check).
  2. To check reading comprehension.
  3. To check vocabulary knowledge.
  4. To check word formation and/or grammatical competence.

If your goal is to test understanding of core concepts or reading comprehension

Write a summary of the concept or reading long enough to adequately test the target's knowledge, but short enough not to induce fatigue. Less than one typed page is probably adequate, but probably considerably less for young students or beginners.

Select words in the text thatare key to understanding the concepts. Thesewill probably be verbs, nouns, and key adverbs.Choose alternatives with one clear answer.

If your goal is to test vocabulary knowledge

Write a text using the target vocabulary. This text should be coherent and cohesive, and be of an appropriate length. Highlight the target words in the text. Choose alternatives with one clear answer.

If your goal is to test word formation/grammar:

Write a text using the target forms. This text should be coherent and cohesive, and be of an appropriate length. Remember that the goal is not vocabulary knowledge, so the core meanings of the stem words should be well known to the students.

Highlight the target words in the text. Provide alternatives with the same word stem, but different affixes. It is a good idea to get a colleague to test the test/exercise to make sure there are no surprises!

Although more often used in formal testing situations MCQs can be used as a testing tool to stimulate thought and discussion on topics students may feel a little reticent in responding to. When designing a MCQ test consider the following:
  • What learning outcomes are the questions testing
  • What intellectual skills are being tested
  • What are the language skills of the audience
  • Gender and cultural issues
  • Avoid grammar language and question structures that might provide clues
Enter the question stem. The quest should be clear and unambiguous. Avoid negative premises as these can tend to be ambiguous.

When building an MCQ consider the following:
  • Use phrases that learners are familiar with and have encountered in their study
  • Keep responses concise
  • There should be some consistency between the stem and the responses
  • Provide enough options to challenge learners to think about their response
  • Try to make sure that correct responses are not more detailed than the distractors
  • Distractors should be incorrect but plausible
Enter the question stem. The quest should be clear and unambiguous. Avoid negative premises as these can tend to be ambiguous.

Enter a question for learners to reflect upon.
Describe how learners will assess how they have done in the exercise (rubrics are useful devices for providing reflective feedback).
University of Auckland

Reflection is a teaching method often used to connect theory to practice. Reflection tasks often provide learners with an opportunity to observe and reflect on their observations before presenting these as a piece of academic work. Journals, diaries, profiles and portfolios are useful tools for collecting observation data. Rubrics and guides can be effective feedback tools.
Enter a question for learners to reflect upon.
Reflective question:

Think about the activities others do for you, the permissions you ask or give, the things you are forced to do or the things you force others to do. Write 10 sentences in your notebook using the causative verbs, try to use different grammatical tenses to practice. Remember to respect the rules in every tense. 

Example: I have had my house decorated last month.  (present perfect)
Describe how learners will assess how they have done in the exercise (rubrics are useful devices for providing reflective feedback).
